metadata.title: A novel high-performance SnO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> catalyst for oxidative desulfurization under mild conditions

Fig. 1 Time-course of DBT oxidation in n-octane using SnO2. catalysts prepared at various calcination temperatures. Experimental conditions: T=333 K, O/S = 10, catalyst dosage=0.08 g/10 mL, t =2 h. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) XRD patterns and (b) FT-IR spectra of SnO2 catalysts prepared at various calcination temperatures. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM images of SnO2 nanoparticles prepared at different calcination temperatures. (a) Untreated, (b) 473 K, (c) 573 K, (d) 673 K, (e) 773 K, (f) 873 K. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of SnO2 nanoparticles prepared at different calcination temperatures. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) NH3-TPD results of SnO2 catalysts prepared at different calcination temperatures. (b) and (c) Narrow scan XPS analysis of an SnO2 catalyst calcined at 673 K. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Effects of (a) reaction temperature, (b) O/S molar ratio, (c) reaction time, and (d) catalyst dosage on ODS. Experimental conditions: T=333 K, O/S = 10, catalyst dosage=0.08 g/10 mL, t=2 h. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Removal of different S-containing compounds versus reaction time. Experimental conditions: T=333 K, O/S = 10, catalyst dosage=0.08 g/10 mL, t=2 h. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) Fitting of experimental data to the pseudo-first-order rate model. (b) Arrhenius activation energies for ODS over SnO2 calcined at 673 K. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Effect of catalyst recycling on the conversion of DBT over SnO2 calcined at 673 K. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The proposed reaction mechanism for DBT oxidation using SnO2 as catalyst, H2O2 as oxidant. Fig. 10 Table 1 Physico-chemical parameters of various samples. Table 1 Catalyst Surface area (m2/g)a Pore volume (cm3/g)b Pore size (nm)c SnO2(Untreated) 8.0 0.007 3.796 SnO2(473 K) 181.5 0.095 2.097 SnO2(573 K) 161.4 0.074 2.091 SnO2(673 K) 152.0 0.116 3.601 SnO2(773 K) 47.9 0.124 9.759 SnO2(873 K) 23.7 0.145 23.243 A novel high-performance SnO2 catalyst for oxidative desulfurization under mild conditions Aili Liu a Mingyuan Zhu a b ⁎ Bin Dai a b a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Shihezi University, Shihezi, Xinjiang, 832000, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Shihezi University Shihezi Xinjiang 832000 PR China b Key Laboratory for Green Processing of Chemical Engineering of Xinjiang Bingtuan, Shihezi, Xinjiang, 832000, PR China Key Laboratory for Green Processing of Chemical Engineering of Xinjiang Bingtuan Shihezi Xinjiang 832000 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Shihezi University, Shihezi, Xinjiang 832000, PR China. School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Shihezi University Shihezi Xinjiang 832000 PR China Graphical abstract The catalyst SnO2 was prepared by a precipitation method, and then aged and calcined at the optimal temperature of 673 K. The reaction conditions were optimized and the oxidation desulfurization efficiency of the obtained catalyst were evaluated. The sulfur removal rate was 99.8% at the optimum reaction conditions of 0.08 g catalyst, 333 K, O/S = 10, 2 h. The catalytic site in the ODS process of the SnO2 catalyst may be Sn4+/Sn2+ Lewis acids. Furthermore, no significant catalytic performance decrease was observed over 14 reuse cycles. The excellent activity and reusability of the catalyst was attributed to the beneficial effects upon specific surface area and acidic-site strength of the appropriate heat treatment temperature. Keywords SnO2 Oxidative desulfurization Calcination Recyclability Acid site 1 Introduction Owing to concerns over environmental deterioration, stringent laws and regulations have been introduced that limit the levels of sulfur in petroleum products to below 10 ppm. Accordingly, an increasing amount of research is being dedicated to reducing the sulfur contents of petroleum products. Desulfurization methods can be classified into hydrodesulfurization [1] and non-hydrodesulfurization [2,3]. Although hydrodesulfurization technology is widely used in industry, it does not completely remove heterocyclic sulfides and their derivatives and requires harsh operation conditions. Therefore, alternative desulfurization techniques, such as extraction, bio-desulfurization, adsorption, photooxidation, and oxidation [4], have been explored. Of these techniques, oxidative desulfurization (ODS) presents advantages such as deep desulfurization ability, economy, and simplicity [5]. Catalyst screening is an important factor in the development of ODS methodology, and many studies have been conducted as a means to identify effective catalysts for ODS processes [6,7]. Organic acid catalysts [8] have been reported to function as highly efficient catalyst for the ODS of model oil. In recent years, heteropoly acids (HPAs) with Keggin-type structures have been widely explored owing to their oxidizing capability and homogeneous characteristics. For example, Huang et al. [9] incorporated phosphotungstic acid into nitrogen-doped onion-like carbon via ultrasonication and impregnation to prepare a catalyst capable of deep desulfurization of the model oil. Metal chlorides have Lewis acid sites and vacant metal ion orbitals, allowing them to be paired with sulfur-containing compounds through lone-pair electrondonation. Accordingly, metal chlorides have been widely researched for application to ODS. For instance, Kumar et al. [10] selectively and directly oxidized phenylmethylene-2-thiohydantoins to their corresponding hydantoin analogs using SnCl2·2H2O. Furthermore, Jiang et al. [11] modified metal chlorides including SnCl2, FeCl3, and ZnCl2 with quaternary ammonium species and applied them to the oxidization of sulfur-containing compounds. The oxidation strengths of the resultant catalysts were reported to follow the order [(C10H21)2(CH3)2N]Cl/FeCl3 >[(C8H17)3CH3N]Cl/FeCl3 >[(C4H9)3CH3N]Cl/FeCl3 >[C10H21(CH3)3N]Cl/FeCl3 >Anhydrous FeCl3 >[(C8H17)3CH3N]Cl/CuCl2 >[(C8H17)3CH3N]Cl/SnCl2 >[(C8H17)3CH3N]Cl/ZnCl2 and the system can be recycled up to six times without significant decrease in activity. Additionally, Li et al. [12] used ionic liquids (ILs) to improve the activities of metal chlorides in ODS, significantly improving thiophene removal efficiency. After ten reuse cycles, the removal rate of thiophene decreased from 81.4% to 78.6%. Zhao and co-workers [13,14] used quaternary ammonium salts and metal halide anions to prepare a coordinated IL (C5H9NO·SnCl2) and a Lewis-acidic IL (Me3NCH2C6H5Cl·2ZnCl2) that act as efficient catalysts for ODS. They reported that, over six reuse cycles, the desulfurization yields achieved with these two catalysts decreased slightly and that the conversion rates decreased from 94.8% and 94% to 93.8% and 91.2%, respectively. Clearly, the use of ammonium salts [13] and ILs [11,12,14] can promote the removal of sulfides by metal halide catalysts. However, although these homogeneous catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performances in ODS processes, they cannot be easily separated and recovered from oil products, and this is currently the main obstacle to industrial application. Compared with homogeneous catalysts, solid-phase catalysts for oxidative desulfurization have the advantages of easy recovery of catalysts and less loss of active components. Based on this, we investigated tin oxide with strong Lewis acid sites and found that SnO2 was first applied to the oxidation of SO2 to SO3 and its hydrolysis to sulfuric acid In 1920, which still plays an important role in environmental protection for industrialized countries. Furthermore, SnO2-based catalysts modified by various methods have also been studied as catalysts for CO oxidation [15,16], alcohol oxidation [17,18], and other catalytic processes [19]. However, SnO2 has not been studied as a catalyst for ODS. Accordingly, the current study demonstrates that ODS using SnO2 nanoparticles may be a viable new strategy for producing cleaner diesel fuels. Herein, we have explored the relationship between the physical and chemical properties of SnO2 nanoparticles and their catalytic properties. Furthermore, the effects of catalyst calcination temperature and process variables such as reaction temperature, O/S molar ratio, reaction time, and catalyst dosage on the catalytic performance of the system were studied in detail. In the catalyst/H2O2 system, SnO2 as a novel catalyst has the advantages of simple preparation method, mild reaction conditions, insoluble in extractants, easy recovery and high reusability. Thus, this study presents new information on the application and development of Sn-based catalysts for ODS processes, and may inform the development of such catalysts for use in other fields. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals were used as received without further purification. Dibenzothiophene (DBT, 99%) and 4, 6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT, 99%) were acquired from J&K Chemical Technology. Benzothiophene (BT, 97%) and thiophene (Th, 99%) were purchased from Aladdin. H2O2 (aqueous solution, 30 wt%) was obtained from Tianjin North Chemical Co., Ltd. n-Octane was obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Tin (IV) chloride pentahydrate (SnCl4∙5H2O) was obtained from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. HCl (36 wt%) and ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH, 25 wt%) were supplied by Tianjin Fuyu Chemical Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of SnO2 The method used for the preparation of SnO2 was similar to that previously described in the literature [20,21]. Briefly, SnCl4∙5H2O (2.85 mmol) was completely dissolved in HCl solution (20 mL) at room temperature with vigorous stirring. Then, the addition of ammonium hydrate changed the pH value of the mixture to 8. The obtained suspension was aged, separated and washed several times until complete elimination of chloride anions. By adding silver nitrate solution to the filtrate, no white precipitation was detected, indicating that chloride ion was completely eliminated. The solid was then vacuum dried at 333 K for 24 h and calcined in a muffle furnace for 2 h at different temperatures under a dry air flow. 2.3 Material characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data was collected using a Bruker advanced D8 X-ray diffractometer with CuK α irradiation (λ=1.5406 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA) using 0.02° steps. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet AVATAR 360 instrument. SnO2 nanoparticles were analyzed by field-emission transmission electron microscopy (Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN). The surface areas and porosity characteristics of the SnO2 nanoparticles were investigated by Brunauer-Emmet-Teller analysis of nitrogen adsorption isotherms obtained at 77 K using a Micromeritics Model ASAP 2020 instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were obtained using a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi instrument. Acidic properties of the SnO2 nanoparticles were measured by ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) using an AutoChem 2720 Instrument in the temperature range 50–800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation The experimental procedure included the preparation of model oil, oxidation of DBT, removal of oxidized product sulfone, and determination of sulfur content. 100 ppmw of sulfur-containing model oil was obtained by dissolving 0.0402 g of DBT in 100 mL of n-octane. In a typical oxidative desulfurization process, 10 mL of model oil and 0.100 g of catalyst were added to a 50 mL round bottom flask, and then the round bottom flask was sonicated in an ultrasonic machine for 5 min to completely disperse the catalyst, and then the mixture was placed at different temperatures. The reaction was carried out under a constant temperature (303–353 K) water bath. After 2 h of reaction, the round bottom flask was taken out, cooled to room temperature, and the solid catalyst was separated from the oxidized model oil by centrifugation. Finally, the model oil was extracted with an equal volume of methanol, and the oxidized product sulfone or sulfoxide after the reaction was removed. The concentration of sulfur was determined by analysis using a WK-2D microcoulometric (Jiangsu Jiang Fen Electro analytical Instrument Co., Ltd.) analyzer. The temperature control of the Coulomb is divided into three sections: the vaporization section (873–923 K), the combustion section (1073–1123 K), and the stabilization section (973–1023 K); the stability of the carrier gas N2 and the combustion gas O2 is achieved by controlling the flow meter. The sulfur removal was calculated using Eq. (1): (1) S u l f u r r e m o v a l % = C 0 - C t C 0 × 100 % S u l f u r r e m o v a l ( % ) = C 0 - C t C 0 × 100 % where C0 (ppm) is the initial sulfur concentration of the model oil and Ct (ppm) is the residual sulfur concentration. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimization of calcination temperatures for SnO2 Fig. 1 shows the DBT removal rate versus reaction time for catalysts calcinated at different temperatures. The removal rate of each catalyst becomes better with time’s increasing. As shown in Fig. 1, the highest desulfurization rate using untreated SnCl4 is 74.0%, and the desulfurization increases rapidly with calcination temperature from 473 K to 673 K. Once the calcination temperature reaches 673 K, the activity of the catalyst plateaus until the temperature reaches 773 K, after which the desulfurization rate decreases rapidly as the calcination temperature increases further. The optimum desulfurization (99.8%) is achieved by the catalyst calcined at 673 K. SnO2 has not been previously reported to be an excellent catalyst for ODS. Accordingly, we conducted a series of characterizations to investigate the relationship between catalyst performance and calcination temperature. 3.2 Characterization of the catalysts XRD analysis was used to investigate the crystalline properties of catalysts prepared at different calcination temperatures. As shown in Fig. 2 a, when the catalyst is calcined below 573 K, the SnO2 obtained is amorphous. However, after calcination for 2 h above 573 K, the SnO2 products are crystalline [22]. The major peaks at 26.61°, 33.89°, 37.95°, 51.78°, 54.75°, 61.87°, 65.937°, 71.242°, and 78.711° can be indexed to the (110), (101), (202), (211), (220), (310), (301), (202), and (321) planes, respectively, of tetragonal-phase SnO2 nanoparticles (JCPDS No. 41-1445) [23,24]. As shown in Fig. 2a, the XRD profiles show significant changes upon heat treatment, demonstrating that the SnO2 crystalline structure tends toward a cassiterite crystal structure with increasing calcination temperature. However, as discussed above, although the diffraction peaks become consistently clearer and sharper, the desulfurization rate first increases and then decreases with calcination temperature. Thus, the activity of the catalyst is independent of the crystal structure. Fig. 2b shows the FT-IR spectra of SnO2 nanoparticles obtained at different calcination temperatures. The absorption peaks near 3425 cm−1and 1628 cm−1 are due to the stretching vibration of hydroxyl groups and the deformation vibration of adsorbed water molecules, respectively [25]. With increasing calcination temperature, the intensity of the adsorbed water peak decreases gradually, but the intensity of the vibration peak near 3425 cm−1 remains relatively constant, which is mainly attributed to the strong adsorptive activity of SnO2 and the formation of hydroxyl groups by the adsorption of oxygen [26]. There are two strong absorption peaks in the 500–700 cm−1 regions, which can be attributed to the vibration of Sn-O bonds. The absorption peak at 675 cm−1is due to the Sn-O stretching vibration peak and the other peak corresponds to O-Sn-O angular vibration [24,27]. Thus, the information obtained from Fig. 2b reveals that SnO2 catalysts were successfully prepared but does not provide any insight into the changes in catalyst performance. Consequently, other characterization techniques were employed to further investigate the calcination-temperature-dependent changes in catalyst activity. In transmission electron microscopy (Fig. 3 ), we can see that the catalyst prepared by calcination below 573 K is flocculent and their distribution is uniform. [28,29]. With increasing calcination temperature from 473 K to 873 K, the SnO2 catalyst particles gradually increase in size. Typically, catalyst particle size is inversely proportional to catalytic performance. However, in this system, the activity of the catalyst first increases and then decreases with calcination temperature. As can be seen from Table 1 , the specific surface area of the uncalcined catalyst is only 8 m2/g and it clearly increases upon calcination. However, when the calcination temperature reaches 773 K, the specific surface area of the catalyst decreases rapidly from about 152 m2/g to 47 m2/g, which explains why the activity of catalyst decreases after 773 K. Furthermore, this phenomenon demonstrates that pure SnO2 particles readily agglomerate [30], whichnegatively affects ODS activity. In summary, the SnO2 nanoparticles exhibit optimal catalytic activity for DBT oxidation after calcination at 673 K. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the catalysts prepared at different calcination temperatures were obtained and are presented in Fig. 4 . The samples calcined at 473 K and 573 K present type-I isothermal adsorption curves. In combination with the data in Table 1, it can be seen that these samples have microporous structures. The other samples present H3-type hysteresis loops and type-IV isotherms, which indicate mesoporous structures [31]. Table 1 shows the pore volumes, pore diameters, and surface areas of the catalysts calcined at different temperatures. When the calcination temperature is higher than 673 K, the growth rate of the nanoparticles increases, the lattice distortion rate decreases, and the structure becomes more completely crystalline. High-temperature calcination causes particles to sinter together, resulting in agglomeration and some small mesopores becoming larger mesopores, leading to smaller specific surface areas. Fig. 5 a shows the NH3-TPD results for the SnO2 catalysts. The desorption peaks in the range 373–503 K represent weakly acidic centers; the desorption peaks for moderately strong acid centers are presented from 503 to 643 K; and the corresponding temperatures for strong acid centers fall in the range 643–923 K. SnO2 is a strong Lewis acid, so the desorption peak around 773 K is due to the desorption of NH3 adsorbed onto the strong Lewis acid sites [32]. With increasing catalyst calcination temperature, the strong acid peak position shifts to higher temperature, clearly indicating that the acidity of the catalyst increases. The NH3 desorption temperature of the catalyst prepared by calcination at 673 K is 823 K, which is higher than that of the catalysts obtained by calcination at other temperatures. This is because high-temperature calcination converts some of the weak acid centers into relatively strong acid centers, leading to an increase in the amount of moderate and strong acid centers in the catalyst. Furthermore, catalyst sintering occurs when the calcination temperature is too high [33]. In conclusion, the SnO2 catalyst calcined at 673 K showed the best acidity properties. Subsequently, the catalyst prepared at 673 K was analyzed using XPS and Fig. 5b and c show its narrow scan Sn 3d and O 1s XPS spectra. The Sn 3d spectrum reveals the presence of the Sn 3d 3/2 (495.7eV) and Sn 3d 5/2 (487.3eV) orbitals in Sn4+ but no signals for metallic Sn (493.2 and 484.8 eV), indicating that all the Sn is present in the form of oxides [34,35]. The O 1s peak is located at 531.19 eV and can be assigned to O2− in the oxide lattice. Fixing of elemental state uniquely and binding energy through XPS test helps to further determine SnO2. 3.3 The effect of reaction conditions for the catalytic activity The effects of different desulfurization reaction conditions on ODS rate were investigated. The specific desulfurization conditions optimized were reaction temperature, O/S ratio, reaction time, and catalyst dosage. Reaction temperature is an important factor in ODS and is of great significance for industrial application of the process. Fig. 6 a shows the ODS conversions at different temperatures. The initial desulfurization rate increases significantly with increasing temperature and then decreases slightly after the optimum temperature. Here the increase in desulfurization rate is mainly due to acceleration of molecular movement and the corresponding increases in collision number and energy between reactants with increasing temperature. Moreover, Sn-peroxide complex formation during the reaction increases with increasing temperature. Therefore, with increasing temperature, the desulfurization efficiency is clearly improved. However, when the temperature exceeds 333 K, the desulphurization efficiency is somewhat reduced. This is because higher temperatures lead to the thermal decomposition of peroxide complexes [36] and hydrogen peroxide. Therefore, 333 K was selected as the optimal reaction temperature. Hydrogen peroxide is a clean oxidant and is a key factor in ODS. Thus, the effect of O/S molar ratio on DBT conversion was examined. As can be seen from Fig. 6b, the desulfurization rate increases from 81% to 100% as the O/S ratio approaches 10 and then slightly decreases thereafter. Theoretically, the optimal O/S ratio should be 2, but the decomposition and volatilization of oxidants and mass transfer resistance of the catalyst affect the reaction process [37]. Although increasing the amount of hydrogen peroxide accelerates the oxidation of DBT, it also increases the amount of H2O present, which hinders the reaction of DBT [38]. The rate of reaction may be controlled by the diffusion of H2O2. If so, when the diffusion limit is reached, adding more hydrogen peroxide will not further increase the reaction rate, but will instead increase the amount of H2O present. Furthermore, excessive use of hydrogen peroxide is uneconomic. Accordingly, under our experimental conditions, an O/S molar ratio of 10:1 is most appropriate. Fig. 6c shows the oxidation of DBT versus temperature, catalyst dosage, and O/S ratio for various reaction times using methanol as an extractant. The ODS of DBT reaches 72% in 30 min and 90.9% in 60 min at 333 K. When the reaction time increases to 120 min, DBT is completely removed from the n-octane. The S removal rate sharply increases with increasing reaction time and then stabilizes after 120 min. Thus, the optimal reaction time is 120 min. Fig. 6d shows S removal rate as a function of catalyst dosage. Clearly, the removal of sulfide becomes more complete with increasing catalyst dosage to a certain point. When the catalyst amount is increased from 0.02 g to 0.08 g, the DBT conversion increases from 81.2% to 99%. This is because an increase in catalyst dosage is beneficial in terms of providing enough active sites for the reaction. However, the DBT conversion remains virtually unchanged upon further dosage increase. Therefore, 0.08 g is the optimal catalyst dosage for our ODS system. 3.4 Comparative evaluation of SnO2 catalyst SnO2 is a new catalyst for catalytic oxidation of DBT. The optimum reaction conditions are as follows: reaction temperature 333 K, O/S = 10, reaction time 120 min, catalyst dosage 0.08 g, the removal efficiency of 10 mL 100 ppm model oil is close to 100%. Compared with the H4SiMo40@SiO2 materials prepared by Zhang et al. [39] and the HPW-PDMAEMA-SiO2 oxidative desulfurization catalysts prepared by Zhu et al. [40], the reaction time, O/S and catalyst usage are reduced, and the service life of the catalysts is also slightly improved. We also examined the relationship between reaction time and ODS rate for different sulfides. The electron densities of the sulfur atoms in 4,6-DMDBT, BT, Th, and DBT are 5.760, 5.739, 5.696, and 5.758, respectively, and the sulfide oxidation rate increases with this increase in electron density. However, steric hindrance by methyl groups also affects sulfide oxidation because the active components are prevented from approaching the sulfur atoms, retarding sulfide oxidation. Fig. 7 shows that the oxidation rates for the sulfur-containing compounds under the optimal reaction conditions follow the order 4,6-DMDBT > DBT > BT > Th [36]. 3.5 Activity energy of the catalyst and possible reaction mechanism We studied the oxidation kinetics at different temperatures in order to better understand the effect of temperature on desulfurization efficiency, and the data are shown in Fig. 8 a. The results reveal that, in the presence of sufficient hydrogen peroxide, there is a certain linear relationship between reaction time and ln Ct/C0 and the catalytic oxidation reaction follows pseudo-first-order kinetics, as shown in Eqs. (2) and (3) [9]. The apparent activation energy of the DBT oxidation reaction is obtained using the Arrhenius formula (Eq. 4) [41] and the data shown in Fig. 8b, where the activation energy over SnO2 is 45.20 kJ/mol. This activation energy is higher than that reported previously [9,41], but the system still exhibits good activity. This is attributed to the previous use of heteropolyacids as an active catalyst component [42]. (2) r = - d C t d t = k C t (3) ln C t / C 0 = - k t (4) l n k = l n A - E a R T The reaction mechanism of oxidation of DBT by SnO2 catalyst was analyzed through experiments (Fig. 9 ). The DBT molecule containing the lone pair electrons loses electrons into DBT.+, and the SnO2 catalyst with strong Lewis acid sites is partially reduced to Sn2+; then the hydrogen peroxide obtains electrons to form active oxygen radicals O.−, enhancing the electrophilicity. At the same time, the Sn2+ reaction loses electrons to convert to Sn4+. DBT.+ adsorbed at the Lewis acid site is oxidized by the reactive oxygen radical to form sulfoxide (DBTO). Through the same oxidation process, the sulfoxide is further oxidized to sulfone, in the process accompanied by the mutual conversion of the Lewis acid sites Sn4+ and Sn2+. In addition, polar compounds are extracted into the methanol phase for separation [42]. 3.6 The reusability of the catalysts Finally, the reusability of the catalyst was investigated. The stability of Sn-based catalysts is typically low wing to their catalytic oxidation in the liquid phase. Accordingly, the recycling and stability of heterogeneous catalysts are very important for industrialization. In the present study, following a reaction, the catalyst was centrifuged, washed by methanol and vacuum drying at 333 K. As shown in Fig. 10 , the number of effective cycles for our solid-phase SnO2 catalyst is significantly increased compared with that of a liquid Sn-based catalyst. The catalytic activity of our catalyst is maintained at approximately 97.4% after 14 reuse cycles. This demonstrates that solid-phase SnO2 catalysts do not undergo significant loss of active components and retain their acidic sites. 4 Conclusions SnO2 nanoparticle catalyst was synthesized by simple aging and calcination method and applied to ODS. The conversion rate of DBT reached 100% and remained at 97.4% after 14 reuses. The excellent activity and recycling ability of catalysts are mainly affected by calcination temperature on the specific surface area and surface acid strength of oxides. The SnO2 catalyst is reacted with hydrogen peroxide to form hydrogen peroxide complexes, which oxidizes DBT molecules on the acidic sites of the catalyst Lewis to achieve DBT removal. The development of SnO2 catalyst provides a new idea and strategy for the production of cleaner diesel oil. coredata.dc:description: The catalyst SnO2 was prepared by a precipitation method, and then aged and calcined at the optimal temperature of 673 K. The reaction conditions were optimized and the oxidation desulfurization efficiency of the obtained catalyst were evaluated. The sulfur removal rate was 99.8% at the optimum reaction conditions of 0.08 g catalyst, 333 K, O/S = 10, 2 h. The catalytic site in the ODS process of the SnO2 catalyst may be Sn4+/Sn2+ Lewis acids. Furthermore, no significant catalytic performance decrease was observed over 14 reuse cycles. The excellent activity and reusability of the catalyst was attributed to the beneficial effects upon specific surface area and acidic-site strength of the appropriate heat treatment temperature.
coredata.dc:title: A novel high-performance SnO2 catalyst for oxidative desulfurization under mild conditions
